title: Couple starved dogs so badly bones were visible through their chests
text:
The couple had previously been warned that their dogs were underweight and needed pasta in their food

A couple have been told they cannot have animals after leaving their dogs to starve for months and failing to take them to the vets.

Laura Butt, 33, and Timothy Wood, 53, kept dogs that were so thin their bones were clearly visible along their rib cages and have now been banned from keeping dogs for three years.

The couple had previously been told to add pasta into the diets of dogs Bear, Molly, Roxy and Rio, who were also covered in deep scratches when they were found at the couple’s home in Draycott, Derbyshire.

Prosecutor Richard Purchase said: ‘There was a worry at that time that two dogs were underweight.

‘Molly, 14, was thin and Roxy, seven, was underweight. Advice was given that the dogs needed cooked pasta into their dog food. It was advised that the dogs should be taken to the vets.’

One of the dogs, referred to in court as HM1, was so badly starved his hips were visible (Picture: BPM)

Some of the dogs were covered in deep scratches and that had not been treated by a vet (Picture: BPM)

But by March this year the couple had failed to take the dogs to the vets with Wood saying it was because they were ‘very busy’.

Inspectors from the RSPCA visited in March but could not get access until May 24 when police attended with Helen Mead from the charity.

Butt warned that Bear, six, was aggressive, but Ms Mead could see he was lethargic with his hip bones visible.

Rio was also grumbling and had scabs.

Mr Purchase said: ‘The fear was that it had a fight with one of the other dogs. The scratches were deep and the dog had not had any treatment.

‘Mr Wood said the dogs were fed a lot of food. Ms Mead asked there was any dog food but Mr Wood said no.

Laura Butt, 33, and Timothy Wood, 53, were banned from keeping animals for three years (Picture: BPM)

‘The concern was that the dogs were not being fed on dog food but scrap food from the local takeaway. It would appear the dogs were so thin because of their diet. All four dogs were seized.’

Mr Purchase added : ‘Advice was ignored between December and May. Ms Mead tried to work with the defendants without the need for legal action.’

The court heard that Miss Butt had ‘found herself in a situation nobody would ever want to find themselves in’.

He added that Molly has since put on weight as well as Bear. All dogs are still with the RSPCA.

They were ordered to pay £1,240 and banned from keeping dogs for three years.
